text:
Trivial patch. No other task gets two definitions, one with all lowercase and
one with mixed case; why should this one? I presume you can still write it in a
build script with whatever mixed case you like. Having both styles in
defaults.properties just confuses tools which analyze this for other purposes,
e.g. an IDE, or <antstructure>.
creator: jglick@apache.org

text:
Task names are case sensitive so one cannot
remove one of these.
There is actually one other that is defined
twice - style and xslt.
creator: peter.reilly@corvil.com
jglick@apache.org
text:
Yes, well that's definitely... odd that you can type e.g.

<echo MeSsAgE="hello"/>

but not

<Echo>hello</Echo>

but oh well.

Re. double definitions - there's also e.g. <javadoc2> vs. <javadoc>. However at
least <javadoc2> is deprecated in the manual and the task logs a runtime warning
if you use it. (Which should probably use MSG_WARN BTW.)

Suggest <WsdlToDotNet> be similarly deprecated as an unnecessary case variant.
And probably <style> could be deprecated as an unnecessary (and perhaps
confusingly vague) synonym for <xslt>.

creator: jglick@apache.org
text:
Putting in a patch for 1.7: deprecating <WsdlToDotnet> and <style>. Let's have
only one recommended name for a single task.

- <WsdlToDotnet> uses mixed case, unlike other task names.

- <style> is vaguer than <xslt> and is also the name of an attribute on the
task, which may be confusing.

text:
<style> is still listed in coretasklist.html in italics (i.e. "deprecated
name"), so I don't *think* it should be hard to find...

Right. Sorry. I guess it just feels weird that all of a sudden I have a bunch 
of builds using an obsoleted task, because you decided so in the 'Do not define 
<wsdltodotnet> twice' PR. I guess I'm a creature of habits and now I have to 
change my habit of using <style>. --DD

text:
Well the deprecation of <style> can certainly be reverted if people object to
it; it's intended to simplify things for the future, but of course it causes
some annoyance in the short term. I had mentioned it in this report without any
response but that was a while back.
